\>is there a distinction?

The Chinese characters used for print have no circular strokes, and differ in this way from the Japanese Hiragana that Eben shows. They are straight, cornered, and curved with various terminals, but never circular. Chinese cursive writing or 'grass script' does have circular strokes but it is not normally printed as text. Incidentally, Kanji is the Japanese translation of Hanzi, the Chinese word for their characters.

Hopefully we're talking about "orientalized" Latin fonts,  
where there really is no difference, certainly not among  
the "users" of such typography.

hhp

I particularly like the way she (Price Hacker) has aligned the I and A with left verticals, for a kind of "flush left, angled right" style.

_doesn’t seem all that close to me._

Or you could say it was feminine, but that's a whole nother dimension of politicization...

The 1925 BB&S catalog shows three faces called Japanet, Pekin, and Bamboo. None of them is truly oriental, but seem to evoke an Eastern exoticism. MacGrew reports that each was originally designed in the late 1800s -- 1893, 1888, & 1889, respectively. Each was also originally marketed under a different name, having nothing to do with the Orient -- Wedge Gothic, Dormer, & Freak, respectively.

Clearly, BB&S was trying to tap a trend. ATF later recast some of these in 1954.

Just an observation/question... When you see the examples posted so far, do you think they look at least vaguely Chinese/Japanese?

Being Korean, I am quite familiar with the Chinese and Japanese scripts, and can't force myself to look at them that way at all. From my cultural background, I honestly couldn't have guessed from appearances alone that the 'faux-Chinese/Japanese' lettering was meant to evoke the appearance of Chinese or Japanese scripts.

The only reason I even knew that this sort of lettering style was meant to be used in contexts that had to do with East Asia was by association; I saw it often used in conjunction with kungfu and samurai themes, Chinese/Japanese restaurants, etc. It took some reflection to even come up with the notion that the lettering was mimicking the East Asian scripts; 'Hmm, the strange modulated curves _could_ resemble the strokes of East Asian calligraphy to those who are not familiar with the scripts,' I thought, not entirely convinced of my own conclusion.

The thing is, there is some quite convincing faux-Japanese lettering out there, some of which at first glance might even fool me into thinking that I'm looking at some genuine Japanese kana. But none of the examples posted so far look really Chinese/Japanese to me. To my mind, this type of lettering really belongs to its own genre besides the more overtly faux-Japanese lettering style, which seems to have come in vogue more recently, possibly owing to anime culture.

\> do you think they look at least vaguely Chinese/Japanese?

In fact to an outsider\* they look _literally_ oriental!

I have a bunch of comments to make now but not much time. So I will limit myself to a single observation for now. The reason that this faux chinese style looks so faux to the insider is that it uses only one of the 8 classic stroke types used in Chinese. The one used for the down & left.

Here is a link to see it & the others if you are keen.

[http://www.chinavoc.com/arts/calligraphy/eightstroke.asp](http://web.archive.org/web/20100124082249/http:/www.chinavoc.com/arts/calligraphy/eightstroke.asp "http://www.chinavoc.com/arts/calligraphy/eightstroke.asp")

- it uses all the stroke types/kinds  
 - it uses Chinese rules ( or nearly) for assembling the letters into radicals with which to make up the finished glyph.

Perhaps any type that looks "brush drawn" seems somewhat Oriental to Westerners.

For instance, Auriol, Hiroshige (of course), and perhaps flare-styles like Optima, Laudatio, and Beorcana.

Auriol (c.1900), because of its Art Nouveau/Aesthetic era provenance, and the disconnected nature of the strokes, more so than the others.

Here is a comparison of the characters drawn by the missionary with a modern font with brush-style appearance. You can get a good idea of how weak and floppy his drawings are. (Properly speaking, characters are written, not drawn.)

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20100124082249im_/http:/typophile.com/files/comparebamboo2_6535.png)

Hrant, 8 is a number I see more often. This is only relevant to brush method; components of the character are talked about in radicals, of which there are more than 300.

One of the biggest differences is that in Chinese calligraphy the brushes are very soft, so there is zero resistance as you are writing. But you do have to pay attention to how the brush tip flicks around. That's very different from using a calligraphic pen. This contributes to (but isn't the determining factor in) a very different esthetic.

"BTW I can’t quite support the idea of faux Chinese fonts being Chinoiserie."

I mentioned Chinoiserie as a probably historical starting point for the emergence of faux Chinese roman letterforms. Sorry for not clarifying. Chinoiserie's importance goes beyond its role as an artistic movement; in Enlightenment Europe, especially England and France, the Chinese imperial system was taken to be highly advanced politically. Rousseau thought that China's system of government most closely represented rule by a philosopher king. This valuation of China then had its influence on artistic and then popular spheres. I wouldn't completely equate Chinoiserie with orientalism, as the latter has a stronger ideological edge.

Fusaka, according to its own description, follows Chinese not with imitated brushstrokes, but by making each letter fit into a square. The extra lines and dots are based on portions of characters, as are many of the letters. The aesthetic of Chinese characters requires each character to be balanced in the context of a square. (Chinese fonts are of course monospaced.) And then in calligraphy, demands for overall page color will influence interaction between characters, especially in the highly cursive 'grassy' styles. In Fusaka the extra dots for example in the J and L make more sense in the context of a square.

Fusaka certainly makes a great deal more sense as you explain it now. Thanks!

Re: Chinoiserie, again you make a great deal of sense there. What I should clarify is that I do not reject the idea that a links can be made. Instead I am maintaining (until I hear a convincing arguement to the contrary) that a font cannot contain or represent anything that complex in itself. That it might show the impact of such a thing is on the other hand a completely acceptable idea to me. My quibble was about the nature of a font rather than about Chinoiserie per se - which I still know far to little about!

Ooh, the thread (along with Typophile) is back.

Timd : <cite>it looks more to me like taking a stroke of a chinese painting of a section of bamboo and using that stroke to create letterforms</cite>

This explanation makes the most sense to me. Reminds me, too, of a Chinese bamboo painting (attributed to Guan Yu, I think) which is in fact a poem/message in disguise: the characters are formed by bamboo leaves. I saw a stele in the 'Stele Forest' in Xian, China that replicated this painting, and I took a photo of the rubbing (apologies for the blurry shot):

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20100124082249im_/http:/typophile.com/files/bamboopoem_6092.jpg)

Clever piece of art, but not what Chinese writing usually looks like.

So I guess this is a case of taking a design element unrelated to script from a culture. A comparable hypothetical example would be if one took the Greek maeander and based a Latin typeface design on it to evoke Greekness.

When I say faux-Japanese, [this](http://web.archive.org/web/20100124082249/http:/991.com/newGallery/Linkin-Park-In-The-End---Live-203058.jpg) is closer to what I'm talking about--lettering that actually imitates Japanese scripts.

The canonical model for basic strokes in Chinese calligraphy is based on the character 永. Depending on how you separate the strokes, you can get either eight or six, I think.

Eben: <cite>Jongseong, how do you feel about the faux stuff? Does it offend you? I was going to relate how my Pal Jeff, who is a Chinese American feels but I am curious to hear from you.</cite>

I take it you mean culturally offended and not, you know, because of bad kerning or whatever. When I see the bamboo-stroke-type faux-Chinese lettering, I just think it's a bit kitsch, but not really offensive. I simply don't know enough about it to find anything offensive. As I said, I'm barely familiar enough with it to know that it's supposed to evoke East Asian culture in the first place.

From my Korean/international background, my take on Chinese/Japanese culture will be very different both from those approaching from a Western cultural background and from Chinese/Japanese backgrounds. I am also curious what a Chinese-American take on faux-Chinese lettering would be like. Do Chinese-Americans embrace this style, or reject it because of whatever reason?

From Sojin Kim & Somi Kim, "Typecast: Meaning, Culture, and Identity in the Alphabet Omelet," _Lift and Separate_ (New York: 1993), 32. (Found mentioned in a comment attached to the _Design Observer_ article linked above.):

"In 1867 one of the earliest pseudo-Japanese fonts was patented in America. This alphabet, known as _Mikita_, consists of three-dimensional letterforms suggestive of wood or lacquer work. Rather than actual mimicry of other alphabets, the first fonts that drew on the Far East in their letter structure were more reflective of concurrent art/design movements (artistic printing, the aesthetic, arts and crafts, international symbolist, art nouveau). [fn: N. Gray, _History of Lettering_, 175] Informal writing styles and brush scripts, particularly Chinese and Japanese, also began to affect character shapes. Around 1885, a font called _Japanese_ appeared in England, perhaps the first font to allude directly to Japanese or other East Asian culture through the design of letters that evoke the calligraphic brushstrokes of Asian writing. [fn: N. Gray, _19c Ornamented Typefaces_, 101, 220] Despite the visual integrity and ingenuity of many of these alphabets, Western letterers' mimicry of calligraphic strokes used by other writing traditions inevitably fails to refer correctly to the \*ductus\*, or order and direction of strokes, of the different traditions."

(And in the second footnote: "_Mikita_ was produced by the type foundry D. & G. Bruce, New York, 1867, and offered as _Novel_ by the English type foundries Austin Wood, c. 1868, and Figgins, c. 1883. A face called _Chinese_ was offered in a supplement to the Bruce specimen book in 1879. _Japanese_ was produced by the English type founder Sir Charles Reed, c. 1885.")
